The process involves using "Insignificance Indicators" to assess the potential impact on air quality. These indicators are based on annual emission thresholds that vary depending on the current air quality status of the area. For areas in clear attainment, a 250 ton/year threshold is used. In areas near nonattainment, lower thresholds apply: 25 tons/year for lead and 100 tons/year for other criteria pollutants. Actions with emissions below these indicators for all criteria pollutants are considered insignificant, meaning they likely won't contribute to exceeding air quality standards. However, exceeding these thresholds doesn't automatically indicate significance; it simply suggests further assessment may be needed.

The preset insignificance indicators used are:

1. 250 tons/year Prevention of Significant Deterioration (PSD) major source threshold for areas "Clearly Attainment" (not within 5% of any NAAQS)

2. General Conformity Rule de minimis values:
   - 25 tons/year for lead
   - 100 tons/year for all other criteria pollutants

These apply to areas "Near Nonattainment" (within 5% of any NAAQS).
